Big Rock
Salinan (Antoniano) · Petroglyph & Bedrock Mortar Site

Prominent rock formation in the San Antonio Valley, Fort Hunter Liggett, southern Monterey County — the heartland of Salinan territory occupied for over 10,000 years.

Abundant bedrock mortar holes indicate intensive long-term acorn processing. Petroglyphs are present on rock surfaces. The summit provides a panoramic view of the valley’s oak savannahs, the San Antonio River, and surrounding creeks. Located within a dense cluster of Salinan sites including Wagon Cave, Santa Lucia Creek Mortars, and the nearby Cueva Pintada (National Register).

The Salinan people speak a Hokan language — believed to be the oldest language family in California. They are divided into Antoniano (north) and Migueleno (south) divisions. Despite over 10,000 years of continuous habitation, the Salinan remain among ~40 California tribes without federal recognition.

The U.S. Army and Desert Research Institute actively document and preserve rock art at Fort Hunter Liggett using D-Stretch imaging technology.

Sources: GJHikes/Rex Nye Map · DRI/FHL Rock Art Documentation Project 2020 · Fort Hunter Liggett Cultural Resources

Wagon Cave
Salinan (Antoniano) · Rock Shelter / Habitation Site

Part of the Wagon Caves formation (~56 acres) northwest of Jolon, Fort Hunter Liggett. One of the most significant Salinan archaeological sites, with evidence of at least two villages: an older occupation (~450 CE) and a later protohistoric settlement (~1450–1650 CE).

Excavations recovered shell beads (used as currency — blue beads were most valuable), stone tools (stemmed biface, lithic flakes), animal bones, charred seeds, and grinding mortars. Fire-scarred cave roofs attest to centuries of habitation. The broader Wagon Cave Research Natural Area (806 acres) protects diverse old-growth Valley Oak stands.

The Salinan Antoniano occupied villages throughout this valley, trading shell beads with the Yokuts for obsidian and seeds, and with the Chumash for shell ornaments and wooden dishes.

Sources: GJHikes/Rex Nye Map · Wikipedia ‘Salinan’ · Cummings et al. 2005 (CA-MNT-307) · USDA Forest Service Passport in Time

Santa Lucia Creek Mortars
Salinan (Antoniano) · Bedrock Mortar / Milling Station

Bedrock mortar complex along Santa Lucia Creek in the San Antonio Valley. Deep circular depressions worn into rock from generations of grinding acorns, seeds, and possibly mineral pigments for pictographs (cinnabar for red, limestone for white, charcoal for black).

The Salinan relied on six species of oak acorns, collected in fall and stored in tall basket granaries made from white willow branches. Creek-side mortar locations reflect the need for water in the leaching process to remove bitter tannins. Research by Jones & Lebow (2015) links Central Coast bedrock mortars primarily to the Late Period and early post-contact era.

Part of a larger habitation and resource processing complex with Big Rock, Wagon Cave, and other San Antonio Valley sites.

Sources: GJHikes/Rex Nye Map · Jones & Lebow 2015 (JCGBA) · DRI/FHL Project 2020

Pinal Creek Site
Salinan (Antoniano) · Habitation / Resource Processing Site

Located along Pinal Creek in the San Antonio Valley, part of a dense cluster of Salinan cultural resources near Fort Hunter Liggett. The creek provided fresh water for acorn leaching, supported surrounding oak woodlands, and offered riparian habitat for fishing and hunting.

Anthropologist Gary Breschini documented over 100 rock art sites in Monterey County, many in remote areas of the Fort Hunter Liggett reservation. The San Antonio Valley was described as the heartland of Salinan habitation — a protected, well-watered setting that supported a large prehistoric population for over 10,000 years. Speakers of a Hokan language were among the first peoples migrating south and west over the Sierra barrier toward the Pacific.

Sources: GJHikes/Rex Nye Map · Monterey County Historical Society · Breschini surveys (referenced in Monterey County NOW)
